title: Summary of Data Sources
text:
This page contains an overview of different types of source software system, where a patient may have data generated and recorded across their healthcare journey. It is not a description of exact systems that exist in different locations, but rather a general classification of systems based on the different types of data that they contain.

Patient administration


Patient administration systems (PAS)
Software that capture non-clinical information about patients, and their activity across different care settings (including all hospitals). Information captured includes identities, demographics, and address, and also captures pathway information such as referrals, waiting lists and appointments, as well as inpatient activity and ward movements or discharge. PAS may be standalone software solutions offered by different suppliers, or may be integrated as a function into Electronic Health Records (EHR) software. PAS also serves as a master patient index for other records in the care location. PAS are joined directly to the national Personal Demographics Service, which is a live, national directory of non-clinical information for patients that is part of the NHS Spine.



Primary care


Patient demographic record
Much like PAS systems, these are parts of a GP Electronic Health Record (EHR) that maintain a record of non-clinical information for patients, including their GP registration history. Patient details across different GP systems are coordinated through a Primary Care Registration Management service and also synced with the Personal Demographics Service. Data may be stored in structured tables containing patient identify, demographic, address, and registration information.


Structured (coded) clinical record
When patients see a clinician, or undergo procedures and tests, or experience medical diagnoses, symptoms, and events, these data are entered into the record as ‘clinical codes’. Coding is performed manually, largely by GPs during or following consultations, or after reviewing letters and results. There are hundreds of thousands of codes that each represent unique clinical concepts, and large vocabularies or dictionaries that define these. The most commonly used for primary care in the NHS is SNOMED CT. Codes are typically stored in tables. A simple example of part of such a table is below:









PATIENT_ID
DATE
CONCEPT_NAME
CONCEPT_CODE




123456789
2020-1-1
Pre-diabetes (disorder)
858301000000107


123456789
2021-1-1
Diabetes mellitus type 2 (disorder)
44054006


123456789
2024-1-1
Retinopathy due to diabetes mellitus (disorder)
4855003





Lab tests and other measurements
Results from tests and other measurements can be entered into the record by clinicians, and are usually stored as separate tables that also capture result values and outcomes. In many cases, where tests originated in primary care and where there is interoperability between pathology services and the EHR, these values are automatically sent into the system once results are ready.


Medications and prescribing data
When a prescription for a medication is generated, either one off or as a repeat prescription, this information is recorded in the GP EHR. This information is directly used to send prescriptions to a dispenser (like a local pharmacy), as well as populating the patient’s Summary Care Record with their current medications. The GP EHR also contains records of requests - such as when a patient asks for a prescription to be renewed.


Unstructured (free text) clinical record
While GPs make effort to code important information about their patients, a large amount of additional information is found in the unstructured, or free text, record. This simply includes blocks of text that are written to describe encounters and other interactions. As part of the medicolegal record, such text typically contains patients’ descriptions of their medical history, symptoms, and other experiences, as well as examination findings and clinical thought process.


Referrals data
Primary care referrals to other services are increasingly centralised through the national e-Referral service, and provide an electronic source of referral data. Some referral pathways remain paper based, but can be used to support statistical reporting through aggregation of referral and waiting list data by referral centres such as hospitals.


Community pharmacy
Most prescriptions are dispensed to patients through designated local pharmacies. While the electronic prescription service produces an electronic record of prescribed items that can be used for reimbursements, a minority of prescription and dispensing data are still conducted through paper based records.



Civil registries


Births and deaths
Births and deaths are reported through established systems of forms and submissions to the level of registration districts. Records here are collated upwards to the General Register Office who hold national records for births and deaths, as well as marriages and civil partnerships.



Public health / screening



Community health / social care



Secondary / tertiary care


Structured (coded) clinical record
Data that is coded at point of care is less common in secondary care when compared to primary care, but some Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems such as Epic enable the entry of standard codes such as SNOMED CT into a patient’s record. More commonly, data may be “semi-structured” through forms or flowsheets, where records are made with specific fields (such as “medical history”, “recorded symptoms”, and “examination findings”).


Unstructured (free text) clinical record
The vast majority of patient data in secondary care is found as free text. This includes narrative that records the details of encounters between clinicians and patients (from admission to ward rounds and discharge), as well as records of procedures and operations, nursing and allied health professinoal notes, and clinical thought processes (for example from a multi-disciplinary meeting). This also includes discharge summaries, clinical letters, and longer reports of investigations such as imaging or pathology.


Lab tests and other measurements


Secondary care medication and dispensing data


Radiology / DICOM


Histopathology slides


Medical device outputs


Other imaging modalities


Genomic testing reports


Cancer data


Referrals and waiting times data



Specialist testing services

title: Introduction
text:
Early preview v0.1
Deep dive into health data architecture, data flows, and data capabilities across NHS England, through detailed schematics and explainers. This is an early proof of concept and a ‘living document’ that will be continually updated. Work is offered open source, under MIT license. Source files found in the Github repository. Feedback and collaboration are invited.
Previous work in mapping data flows found in Zhang, Morley et al., 2023 and Data Insights UK. This last work, conducted to support recommendations of Better, Broader, Safer 2022, was focused on high-level but comprehensive understanding of what individual flows existed (est. 60,000 in one year) and who was extracting and using data. The new work, hosted here, is focused on a cross-section of systems, technical architectures, and extraction mechanisms, that are key to informing feasibility and gap analysis for technical data programmes.

title: National Schematic
text:
Early preview v0.1
The diagram below illustrates data flows that meet the following criteria.

On a national scale (spanning all NHS regions)
Occur electronically (data is managed electronically and systematically collected via API)
Managed systematically (the same documented process is reproduced across all extractions and transfers).

Each category of data flows can be toggled. These, and source systems, are described in subsections. The diagram may take 30 seconds to load. Best viewed in desktop/laptop computer web browser, and in full screen.
